sentence.text: We report on a female patient with bilateral acoustic neurinomas and other tumors in the central nervous system (neurofibromatosis type 2: negative regulation of cell proliferation) and the constitutional translocation, t(4;22) (q12;q12.2).

The precise identification of the translocation breakpoint (q12.2) on chromosome 22 implies the refined localization of a gene responsible for negative regulation of cell proliferation, and would provide a clue to its molecular characterization and to the isolation of the gene.
Chromosomes of a paraspinal neurinoma from the patient were also analyzed, and the same karyotype as seen in cultured peripheral lymphocytes was found.
The patient's father was also a carrier of the translocation, but he had no clinical symptoms of negative regulation of cell proliferation, nor did other relatives.
Several explanations are offered for the different expression of the translocation between the patient and her father.
